Recent Projects

DARPA Learning Introspective Control (LINC) Project

I am the Technical Lead for the DARPA LINC project at ARCL. Our motivation is that traditional control systems can't handle unexpected conditions or damage outside their original design, and fixing them often takes specialized expertise and significant time.

LINC aims to develop machine learning methods that allow physical systems, like vehicles, ships, drone swarms, and robots, to adapt in real time to unforeseen events. LINC continuously compares sensor data to a learned model, detects critical changes, updates control laws as needed, and communicates those updates to the operator. This enables rapid recovery, keeps operators informed, and maintains trust and control even in unpredictable situations.

Fault Detection, Isolation and Recovery (FDIR) Algorithms (TII Project)

Modern multi-spacecraft missions rely on fleets of small, diverse satellites working together to achieve complex goals. However, ensuring the health and reliability of each spacecraft, and quickly identifying faults among their many sensors and actuators, is a major challenge. Hardware differences, limited communications, and potential fault cascades make traditional detection techniques insufficient. This project develops scalable, decentralized algorithms to automatically detect and isolate faults, enabling resilient and autonomous space missions.
